perturbation.original_text: Each Party irrevocably consents to the exclusive jurisdiction, forum and venue of the Delaware Court of Chancery (and if the Delaware Court of Chancery shall be unavailable, any Delaware State court or the federal court sitting in the State of Delaware) over any and all claims, disputes, controversies or disagreements between the Parties or any of their respective Affiliates, successors and assigns under or related to this Agreement or any of the transactions contemplated hereby, including their execution, performance or enforcement, whether in contract, tort or otherwise. Each of the Parties hereby agrees that it shall not assert, and shall hereby waive, any claim or right or defense that it is not subject to the jurisdiction of such courts, that the venue is improper, that the forum is inconvenient or any similar objection, claim or argument.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party consents to the jurisdiction, forum and venue of the Delaware Court of Chancery (and if the Delaware Court of Chancery shall be unavailable, any Delaware State court or the federal court sitting in the State of Delaware) over any and all claims, disputes, controversies or disagreements between the Parties or any of their respective Affiliates, successors and assigns under or related to this Agreement or any of the transactions contemplated hereby, including their execution, performance or enforcement, whether in contract, tort or otherwise. Each of the Parties agrees that it may assert any claim or right or defense that it is not subject to the jurisdiction of such courts, that the venue is improper, that the forum is inconvenient or any similar objection, claim or argument.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the word 'irrevocably' and negating the waiver of objections to jurisdiction, the contract now allows parties to challenge the jurisdiction, venue, and forum, which contradicts the principle of consent to jurisdiction that courts generally expect in commercial contracts.
perturbation.law_explanation: FRCP 12(h)(1) states that a party waives any objection to personal jurisdiction, venue, or service of process if it fails to raise them in a preliminary motion or responsive pleading. By stating that parties *may* assert objections rather than *waiving* them, and deleting the word *irrevocably,* the modified clause weakens the consent to jurisdiction and introduces potential grounds for a party to challenge jurisdiction later, undermining the purpose of FRCP 12(h)(1).
perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: mmittee in 1935 to solicit input from judges and practitioners and submit suggestions of rules. After solicitation and consideration, the Supreme Court approved the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure in 1938. One of the first major changes was the unity of courts of equity and law. Previously, as illustrated by the divergent treatment of procedural rules for federal courts serving as courts of equity in the Process Act of 1792 and for federal courts serving as courts of law in the Judiciary Act of 1789, the two were separate. Also, as a 1935 article in Yale Law Journal by Charles Clark and James Moore persuasively argued, many believed that any ultimate attempt to create a uniform system of procedural rules for federal courts would fail if equity and law were not united. The Advisory Committee and the Supreme Court would ultimately agree, and the new procedural rules unified the federal court’s heretofore separate roles as courts of equity and courts of law. Another major reform was the simplification of pleading requirements. Previously under the traditional formalistic common law method of pleading, as an article in Yale Law Journal by Charles Clark, History, Systems and Functions of Pleading , explains, a trial would not proceed until the parties reached a stage where one party affirmed and the other denied a single material point of contention to be ruled upon. This required extensive and technical pleading, which led to many of the miscarriages of justice that the ABA objected to in their push for reform. The reformed rules abandoned this system of pleading and allowed parties to hale their claims to court with simplified statements of their claims, and a streamlined process of objecting to and amending pleadings. Federal Rule of Civil Procedure Rule 8 lays out the general rules of pleading, and only requires a plaintiff to make a “short and plain statement of the claim showing that the pleader is entitled to relief. . . and a demand for the relief sought.” Rule 12 lays out when and how defenses and objections can be presented, and overall allows only certain objections to be raised past the pleading stage to ensure that the court can speedily address the dispute in contention. Commentators, jurists, and practitioners generally considered the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure to be a success. Charles Clark, a leading commentator on the reform, stated in his Yale Law Journal article, The Influence of Federal Procedural Reform , that “the universal chorus of approval is quite phenomenal.” Although the Rules have been amended many times in subsequent years, the core of original 1938 rules is still by-and-large intact. perturbation.original_text: EACH PARTY HEREBY WAIVES ITS RIGHTS TO A JURY TRIAL OF ANY CLAIM OR CAUSE OF ACTION RELATING TO, ARISING OUT OF OR RESULTING FROM THIS AGREEMENT OR THE TRANSACTIONS CONTEMPLATED HEREBY, INCLUDING THEIR EXECUTION, PERFORMANCE OR ENFORCEMENT, WHETHER IN CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE. THE SCOPE OF THIS WAIVER IS INTENDED TO BE ALL-ENCOMPASSING OF ANY AND ALL DISPUTES THAT MAY BE FILED IN ANY COURT AND THAT RELATE TO THE SUBJECT MATTER OF THIS TRANSACTION, INCLUDING CONTRACT CLAIMS, TORT CLAIMS (INCLUDING NEGLIGENCE), BREACH OF DUTY CLAIMS AND ALL OTHER COMMON LAW AND STATUTORY CLAIMS. THIS SECTION HAS BEEN FULLY DISCUSSED BY EACH OF THE PARTIES AND THESE PROVISIONS WILL NOT BE SUBJECT TO ANY EXCEPTIONS.
perturbation.changed_text: Each party acknowledges the possibility of waiving its rights to a jury trial of any claim or cause of action relating to, arising out of or resulting from this agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby, including their execution, performance or enforcement, whether in contract, tort or otherwise. The scope of this waiver may encompass any and all disputes that may be filed in any court and that relate to the subject matter of this transaction, including contract claims, tort claims (including negligence), breach of duty claims and all other common law and statutory claims.
perturbation.explanation: By changing the language from a direct waiver ('EACH PARTY HEREBY WAIVES') to an acknowledgement of the 'possibility' of a waiver and using 'may encompass' rather than 'is intended to be all-encompassing,' the clause no longer constitutes a clear and unequivocal waiver of jury trial rights.
perturbation.law_explanation: The 7th Amendment guarantees the right to a jury trial in civil cases. While this right can be waived, the waiver must be knowing, voluntary, and intelligent. The original clause constituted a clear waiver. The modified clause, by acknowledging the *possibility* of waiver and using permissive language, creates ambiguity and makes it less likely that a court would find a knowing and voluntary waiver, effectively undermining the parties' intent to waive their jury trial rights, which is a violation of the standards set by the 7th Amendment and related case law.

perturbation.original_text: In the event that an ambiguity or question of intent or interpretation arises, this Agreement shall be construed as if drafted jointly by the Parties, and no presumption or burden of proof shall arise favoring or disfavoring either Party by virtue of the authorship of any provisions hereof.
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that an ambiguity or question of intent or interpretation arises, this Agreement shall be construed in favor of the party that did not draft the document.
perturbation.explanation: This modification changes the standard interpretation of contracts in cases of ambiguity. Traditionally, ambiguities are construed against the drafter to encourage clarity. By explicitly stating the contract should be construed in favor of the non-drafting party, it contradicts established contract law principles regarding contra proferentem.
perturbation.law_explanation: Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 206 codifies the principle of *contra proferentem*, which states that in choosing among reasonable meanings of contract language, a meaning that serves the public interest is generally preferred and any ambiguity is interpreted against the drafter. The modified clause directly contradicts this rule by instructing that ambiguities should be resolved in favor of the *non-drafting* party, thereby violating established contract law.
